passage.text: Levofloxacin oxidation by ozone and hydroxyl radicals: Kinetic study, transformation products and toxicity
Relevant resource
True|False
Abstract

This work was carried out to investigate the fate of the antibiotic levofloxacin upon oxidation with ozone and hydroxyl radicals. A kinetic study was conducted at 20 °C for each oxidant. Ozonation experiments were performed using a competitive kinetic method with carbamazepin as competitor. Significant levofloxacin removal was observed during ozonation and a rate constant value of 6.0 × 104 M−1 s−1 was obtained at pH 7.2. An H2O2/UV system was used for the formation of hydroxyl radicals HO . The rate constant of HO was determined in the presence of a high H2O2 concentration. The kinetic expressions yielded a kHO /LVF value of 4.5 × 109 M−1 s−1 at pH 6.0 and 5.2 × 109 M−1 s−1 at pH 7.2. These results were used to develop a model to predict the efficacy of the ozonation process and pharmaceutical removal was estimated under different ozonation conditions (i.e. oxidant concentrations and contact times). The results showed that levofloxacin was completely degraded by molecular ozone during ozonation of water and that hydroxyl radicals had no effect in real waters conditions. Moreover, LC/MS/MS and toxicity assays using Lumistox test were performed to identify ozonation transformation products. Under these conditions, four transformation products were observed and their chemical structures were proposed. The results showed an increase in toxicity during ozonation, even after degradation of all of the observed transformation products. The formation of other transformation products not identified under our experimental conditions could be responsible for the observed toxicity. These products might be ozone-resistant and more toxic to Vibrio fisheri than levofloxacin.
Tables
UV characteristics and main fragment ions obtained from MS and MS/MS analyses of LVF and ozonation transformation products.

LVF oxidation in the H2O2/UV system and the contribution of direct photolysis (from modelization) at 20 °C; [LVF]T,0 = 5 μM; experiment (a) [H2O2]0 = 50 mM; and experiment (b) [H2O2]0 = 100 mM.
Contribution of HO radicals to LVF ozonation in real waters. (a) [LVF]T,t/[LVF]T,0 = f(Ct) with Ct = ∫[O3]dt; (b) fHO = f(Rct).

Toxicity patterns and by-product formation during LVF ozonation [LVF]T,0 = 1 g L−1; [O3]0 = 6 mg min−1; pH = 7.2; T = 20 °C (samples diluted to 1/100).
keywords
['Levofloxacin', 'Ozonation', 'H2O2/UV', 'Kinetic', 'By-products', 'Toxicity']
Introduction

The presence of pharmaceuticals in surface and ground waters was reported for the first time in 1977 with the detection of clofibric acid in sewage treatment plant effluents in USA (Hignite and Azarnoff, 1977). After oral administration, metabolized and unmetabolized pharmaceuticals are excreted and directly discharged into the sewage system. Other sources of this environmental pollution include industrial discharges, unproper disposal of unused medicines and emissions related to the use of veterinary drugs. Several investigations showed that antibiotics were not totally removed during wastewater treatment (). Fluoroquinolones are widely used and not readily biodegradable synthetic antibiotics (Al-Ahmad et al., 1999). Levofloxacin (LVF) is a fluoroquinolone used to treat severe bacterial and nosocomial infections, since it has substantial activity against Gram-positive bacteria along with broad Gram-negative coverage. A study conducted on Japanese wastewater treatment plants showed that LVF was not completely eliminated (Yasojima et al., 2006). In this study, LVF was detected in the influents at a concentration of 552 ng L−1 and a removal efficiency of 42% was shown after activated sludge treatment. Moreover, the presence of LVF in aquatic environment was confirmed in a recent study with detected concentrations of up to 87.4 ng L−1 in several surface waters (Kim et al., 2009b). When released into the environment, antibiotics can affect aquatic organisms and cause bacterial resistance. Many investigations have focused on the toxicity of antibiotics to aquatic organisms (). Researches on the toxicity of seven fluoroquinolones to five aquatic organisms showed that EC50 values (median effective concentration) ranged from 7.9 to 23 μg L−1 (Robinson et al., 2005). Measures devoted to reducing the environmental impact of pharmaceuticals have to be studied in order to avoid these potential adverse effects. Ozonation is one current well known advanced water treatment strategy and its potential for pharmaceutical removal is thus of interest. Ozone is a strong oxidant used in drinking water treatment plants, as well as in wastewater treatment to remove microorganisms, inorganic ions and organic pollutants (). During ozonation, like other advanced oxidation processes (such as H2O2/UV), HO radicals that are known to be highly reactive oxidants can be generated. The degradation of many pharmaceuticals by ozone and advanced oxidation processes has been reported in the literature (). Paracetamol, clofibric acid, and diclofenac oxidation by ozonation and H2O2/UV process has been separately investigated by different authors (). Concerning LVF, De Witte et al. (2009) proposed reaction pathways from identification of ozonation by-products of LVF. Lam and Mabury (2005) reported a value for the HO radical rate constant but no value for ozone was provided. In this paper, kinetic oxidation of LVF by ozone and hydroxyl radicals is discussed. Second order rate constants were determined at pH 7.2 and 6.0 for HO radicals, and for the first time for ozone at pH 7.2. For ozone kinetic studies, ozonation experiments were conducted using a competitive kinetic method in the presence of carbamazepine (CBZ) as competitor and an excess of tert-butanol as HO scavenger. LVF removal by H2O2/UV process was studied to determine the HO radical rate constant. Some ozonation transformation products were tentatively identified by LC/MS/MS and are discussed regarding previous findings (De Witte et al., 2009). Finally, the monitoring of toxicity (Vibrio fisheri marine bacteria) during ozonation of LVF was presented for the first time.
Materials and methods
Chemicals and stock solutions

All chemicals were of analytical grade and used without further purification. LVF and CBZ were obtained from Sigma Aldrich (purity ⩾ 98%). Tert-butanol (99.5%) was purchased from Acros Organics. Phosphate buffers, Na2S2O3, colorimetric agents and reductants were purchased from Fisher Scientific and Prolabo. Pure water (resistivity = 18.2 MΩ cm) obtained from a Millipore MilliQ system was used for solution preparation. Stock solutions of pharmaceuticals were prepared daily at the appropriate concentrations. Ozone was produced from oxygen using a Trailigaz generator. An aqueous solution of dissolved ozone (11–21 mg L−1) was used in the kinetic ozonation experiments. This solution was prepared by bubbling ozone in a semi-continuous reactor (800 mL) containing unbuffered pure water. For the H2O2/UV system, hydrogen peroxide was introduced in the reactor after diluting the commercial solution (30%) supplied by Fluka.
Experimental setup for the ozonation experiments
Kinetic study

Due to the high reactivity of ozone with LVF, the kinetic experiments were conducted using the competitive method. CBZ was chosen as competitor on the basis of the value of the second order rate constant with ozone i.e. 7.81 × 104 M−1 s−1 at pH 7.2 (Andreozzi et al., 2002). In order to study the reactivity of molecular ozone, tert-butanol was added to the aqueous solutions to scavenge the HO radicals formed by ozone decomposition in these solutions. The experiments were carried out in a series of volumetric flasks (100 mL). 100 mL of solutions buffered with phosphate at pH 7.2 (ionic strength 2 × 10−3 M) containing LVF (1 μM), CBZ (1 μM) and tert-butanol (3.165 mM) were introduced in the reactor. At t = 0, 1.2 mL of solution containing various proportions of the stock solution of dissolved ozone and pure water (0–1.2 mL) were added to all reactors. The initial ozone concentrations ranged from 0 to 4.5 μM. After complete ozone consumption, residual LVF and CBZ concentrations were determined by liquid chromatography (LC). Under these conditions, since LVF and the reference compound CBZ were simultaneously present in the reaction system and based on second order rate laws, the kinetic expressions for the ozone reaction can be integrated as follows: ln[LVF]T,n[LVF]T,0=kO3/LVFkO3/CBZln[CBZ]T,n[CBZ]T,0 where kO3/LVF and kO3/CBZ are the second-order rate constants for the reaction of ozone with LVF and the reference compound CBZ respectively. The different ozone doses are represented by n. For each experiment, the kO3/LVF/kO3/CBZ ratio was obtained from the representation of ln [LVF]n/[LVF]0 versus ln [CBZ]n/[CBZ]0 and the second-order rate constant of LVF (kO3/LVF) was determined from the second order rate constant of CBZ (kO3/CBZ=7.81×104M-1s-1) reported in the literature (Andreozzi et al., 2002).
Identification of transformation products and toxicity

Experiments were conducted with an initial LVF concentration of 1 g L−1 so as to better assess the toxicity of the oxidation transformation products. This concentration was chosen on the basis of the EC50 and EC20 values of LVF towards V. fisheri determined in a preliminary toxicity test (EC50 = 1.15 g L−1; EC20 = 0.71 g L−1). To monitor the toxicity and to identify ozonation transformation products, experiments were conducted in a 200 mL semi-continuous reactor containing LVF solution (1 g L−1) without adding tert-butanol as scavenger. The pH was fixed at 7.2 by adding phosphate buffer (ionic strength 0.2 M). Ozone was introduced continuously into the reactor at a 6 mg min−1 flow rate. At different time intervals, 2 mL samples were withdrawn for the analyses of transformation products by LC coupled with a photo diode array detector and a mass spectrometer. Additional 0.5 mL samples were also taken for toxicity measurement in Lumistox 300.
Experimental setup of the H2O2/UV system

Hydrogen peroxide photolysis was used as oxidation system to determine the rate constant of LVF with HO radicals (kHO /LVF), H2O2+2hν→2HO Experiments were performed at 20 °C in a 5 L cylindrical batch reactor equipped with a low-pressure mercury vapour lamp (HANAU NN 40/20) enclosed in a quartz sleeve in axial position (6.3 cm optical width). The lamp emits a monochromatic radiation at 253.7 nm. The incident photonic flux I0 was determined by chemical actinometry using a 0.05 M hydrogen peroxide solution (Nicole et al., 1989). The experiments were conducted either at pH 6.0 without adding phosphate buffer or at pH 7.2 adjusted with phosphate buffer. At regular irradiation time intervals, samples were withdrawn for LVF and H2O2 analyses. Specific experimental conditions were selected to simplify the kinetic expressions. An excess H2O2 concentration was chosen as compared to that of LVF so that UV radiation would be mainly absorbed by H2O2. Thus, the Eq. (3) was validated. R=εH2O2[H2O2]0εH2O2[H2O2]0+εLVF[LVF]T,0>0.92 where [H2O2]0 = 50 or 100 mM; [LVF]T,0 = 5 μM; εH2O2=18.6M-1cm-1 (at 254 nm and pH < 9) and εLVF=14,860M-1cm-1 (at 254 nm and pH 6.0; determined in this work). The production of hydroxyl radicals from the H2O2 photolysis (Eq. (2)) is thus given by the following equation: d[HO ]dt=-2d[H2O2]dt≈2φH2O2I0V(1-10-εH2O2l[H2O2]) where I0 = 10.1 × 10−6 E s−1; V = 5 L, the volume of the reactor; φH2O2=0.5molmol-1, the quantum yield of H2O2 photolysis at 254 nm; l = 6.3 cm, the path length in the 5 L cylindrical reactor. The HO radicals formed under high H2O2 concentration conditions were mostly consumed by H2O2. Then, assuming that kHO /H2O2[H2O2]0>50kHO /LVF[LVF]T, the consumption of HO radicals is formulated as: -d[HO ]dt≈kH2O2/HO [H2O2][HO ] From the steady-state hypothesis for radical species, the expression of HO concentration is given: [HO ]ss=2φH2O2I0V(1-10-εH2O2l[H2O2])kH2O2/HO [H2O2] Moreover, when H2O2 concentration was high, the removal of H2O2 by photolysis (and consumption by HO ) followed a zero order kinetic pattern (-d[H2O2]/dt=2φH2O2I0/V). It was calculated that for [H2O2]0 ≈ 50 or 100 mM, the global rate of H2O2 removal by photolysis and reaction with HO radicals was below 150 μmol min−1. Therefore, the H2O2 concentration could be considered constant during the experimental time (12 min) and [HO ]ss could be determined. Consequently, under the experimental conditions used, the kinetic expression for the removal of LVF by HO radicals became a pseudo first order expression and could be easily integrated: -d[LVF]Tdt=kHO /LVF[HO ]ss[LVF]T=kobs[LVF]T From the slope kobs of ln([LVF]T,t/[LVF]T,0)=f(t) and Eq. (6), the rate constant of the reaction of HO with LVF (kHO /LVF) can be calculated.
Analytical procedures

Depending on the concentration levels, hydrogen peroxide was measured by either the iodometric method (Masschelein and Fransolet, 1977) or the colorimetric titane method (Eisenberg, 1943). The Indigo method was used to determine the dissolved ozone concentration in water (Bader and Hoigné, 1981). pH was measured with a MeterLab pH meter (the pH varied by more than 0.2 throughout the experiments). An Alliance Waters 2695 LC system equipped with a Kromasil C18 column (250 mm × 4.6 mm, 5 μm) and a UV–Vis Waters 2487 Detector was used to monitor the residual LVF and CBZ during the oxidation experiments. For each sample, the injected volume was 100 μL and UV detection at 295 and 284 nm was used for LVF and CBZ respectively. The mobile phase was a mixture of methanol/water (acidified with 0.1% acetic acid) at a 1 mL min−1 flow rate. For the identification of degradation products, samples were analysed by LC/UV and LC/UV/MS. The chromatographic device was equipped with a photo diode array detector (Thermo electron) and an ion trap mass spectrometer (Thermo DECA XP Ion max). A. Kromasil C18 column (250 mm × 3.2 mm, 5 μm) was used for each sample. The injected volume was 100 μL and the analyses were performed in an isocratic mode with methanol/water (17/83 v/v, acidified with 0.1% acetic acid) and a 0.3 mL min−1 flow rate. Mass spectrometry detection was conducted with the atmospheric pressure chemical ionisation (APCI) in both positive and negative modes. In both cases, a mass range TIC of 50-750 amu, an ion transfer capillary temperature of 250 °C, an APCI vaporizer temperature of 450 °C, a sheath gas flow of 72 au and a Corona discharge of 5 μA were used. For MS/MS analyses the following working conditions were used: 5 amu isolation width, 30 ms activation time, stability parameter qz at 0.25 and normalised collision energy from 27% to 35% of the voltage amplitude applied to the end-cap electrode. The toxicity of LVF and ozonation transformation products was evaluated by a luminescence test using V. fisheri (NRRLB-11177) bacteria. Lyophilized bacteria were first reactivated in 2% NaCl solution and kept at 15 °C. Bacteria luminescence was measured before sample addition (0 min) and after 30 min incubation on a luminometer (Lumistox 300). The EC50 and EC20 of LVF were determined from different dilution ranges according to the European standards (NF/EN/ISO 11348-3, AFNOR, 1999). A similar protocol was used (with or without dilutions of the samples) to measure the transformation product toxicity. For each sample, the salt concentration was adjusted to 2% by adding solid NaCl in the samples immediately after ozonation.
Results
Kinetic study
Rate constant for reaction with ozone

Fig. 1 presents the ln [LVF]T,n/[LVF]T,0 versus ln [CBZ]T,n/[CBZ]T,0 data obtained from the simultaneous ozonation of LVF and CBZ at pH 7.2 and 20 °C. The results show linear plots with correlation coefficients higher than 0.98. A second order rate constant was calculated for each set of experiments. A mean value of 6.0 (±0.2) × 104 M−1 s−1 was found for the second order rate constant of LVF with ozone at pH 7.2 and 20 °C. No rate constant of LVF ozonation is currently available in the literature. However, a value of 1.5 × 105 M−1 s−1 for enrofloxacin, another fluoroquinolone with a tertiary amine function in its structure, has been reported (Dodd et al., 2006).
Rate constant for reaction with HO

Prior to the experiments with the H2O2/UV system, LVF photodegradation was investigated in order to evaluate the impact of direct photolysis in the system. Quantum yield of 1.17 ± 0.05 × 10−3 and 3.03 ± 0.10 × 10−3 mol mol−1 were found at pH 6.0 and 7.2 respectively (the pH dependence could be due to the LVF pKa values of 5.33 and 8.07). In order to determine the rate constant of HO with LVF, experiments were conducted in the H2O2/UV system in the presence of a high H2O2 concentration (50 or 100 mM) relative to the initial LVF concentration. Under these experimental conditions, the contribution of LVF photolysis in the system can be modelled from Eqs. on the basis of the quantum yield value and the relative absorbance of LVF. -d[LVF]Tdt=φLVFI0VεLVF[LVF]TεH2O2[H2O2] ln[LVF]T,t[LVF]T,0=-φLVFI0VεLVFεH2O2[H2O2]t Fig. 2 shows the variation in the LVF concentration during irradiation in the presence of H2O2 and the contribution of LVF photolysis. H2O2 and LVF analyses during irradiation confirmed the assumption mode for the kinetic expressions (). (i) the H2O2 concentration remained constant (less than 5% decrease); (ii) the removal of LVF due to direct photolysis was negligible compared to the degradation obtained in the H2O2/UV system (Fig. 2); (iii) time-course plots of ln [LVF]T,t/[LVF]T,0 followed a straight line passing through the origin and confirmed the pseudo-first order rate law for LVF removal. The slope of ln([LVF]T,t/[LVF]T,0)=f(t) lead to the determination of the observed rate constant kobs and the second order rate constant kHO /LVF (Eqs. ). The kHO /LVF values at pH 6.0 and pH 7.2 were found to be 4.5 × 109 and 5.2 × 109 M−1 s−1 respectively. These values are in close agreement with the 6.6 × 109 M−1 s−1 rate constant recently determined in the dark Fenton system (Lam and Mabury, 2005).
Modelling ozonation in natural waters

The kHO /LVF and kO3/LVF rate constants determined in this work for the reaction of LVF with molecular ozone and HO radicals provides the information necessary to predict the fate of LVF during ozonation of different real waters. In real water, ozone can react with OH− hydroxide ions to generate HO . Therefore, during ozonation, pollutants can be degraded by the direct action of molecular ozone and/or by the indirect action of hydroxyl radicals formed in situ. Accordingly, the kinetics of LVF oxidation during ozonation of water can be formulated as follows: -d[LVF]dt=kHO /LVF[HO ][LVF]T+kO3/LVF[O3][LVF]T O3 and HO concentrations are needed to predict LVF degradation during ozonation in real waters. Since the HO concentration would be difficult to measure with a simple analytical method and can vary according to the real water considered, the Rct concept described by Elovitz and Von Gunten (1999) can be used. The Rct is defined by the ratio of the HO exposure to the O3 exposure (Rct = ∫[HO ]dt/∫[O3]dt). These authors assumed that Rct is constant in water during ozonation after an initial phase. Therefore, the Rct also represents the ratio of the HO radical concentration to the ozone concentration and substitution of Rct in Eq. (10) gives Eqs. . -d[LVF]Tdt=(kHO /LVFRct+kO3/LVF)[O3][LVF]T ln[LVF]T,t[LVF]T,0=-(kHO /LVFRct+kO3/LVF)∫[O3]dt=-(kHO /LVFRct+kO3/LVF)Ct In natural waters Rct values from 10−9 to 10−7 are usually reported in the literature (Von Gunten, 2003). LVF degradation in waters can be modelled based on Eq. (13). By considering two Rct values, Fig. 3 shows no impact of the Rct value (10−9 and 10−7) on the kinetics of LVF degradation. Therefore, the HO concentration would not influence the LVF ozonation kinetics under water treatment conditions. The fraction of LVF reacting with HO radicals (fHO ) can be determined by considering Eq. (13). The data in Fig. 3 confirm that the contribution of HO radicals in LVF ozonation can be neglected under natural water conditions (i.e. for Rct values below 10−7). fHO =kHO /LVF[LVF]T[HO ]kHO /LVF[LVF]T[HO ]+kO3/LVF[LVF][O3]=kHO /LVFRctkHO /LVFRct+kO3/LVF As shown in Fig. 3, LVF would be completely degraded during drinking water treatment for ozone exposure far below 10 mg min L−1. A 1.38 s half life was estimated for an 0.4 mg L−1 ozone concentration.
Ozonation product identification and toxicity study
Product identification and reaction pathways

Four transformation products (I, II, III and IV) were observed by LC/UV and MS analyses. Transformation products were identified from samples after ozonation times of 5–90 min. The overall UV, MS and MS/MS characteristics of the transformation products and LVF peaks are presented in Table 1. Only the positive APCI mode is presented due to the higher response in positive mode for both LVF and transformation products. However, a response in negative APCI mode was also observed in the case of products I and II. The MS spectra of products III and IV clearly showed a protonated molecular ion at m/z 348 and 324 respectively. Molecular masses of 347 and 323 g mol−1 can thus be expected for these compounds. For these two products, like LVF, an MS/MS fragmentation spectrum of m/z 348 or m/z 324 gives an ion at m/z 304 (−44) or m/z 280 (−44) which could correspond to CO2 loss. In the case of product IV, an additional ion at m/z 304 (−20) which could have been the result of HF loss was also observed. The chemical structures presented in Table 1 were assumed on the basis of the mass differences of −14 and −38 between the molecular ions of these products and LVF. The chemical structure of product IV is in agreement with the observed UV spectrum that lacked the 296 nm band (quinolonic absorption band) as compared to LVF. Due to the probably low stability of products I and II in the APCI source, numerous ion fragments were observed in their MS spectra. However, for these two products, protonated molecular ions at m/z 382 and 354 corresponding to molecular masses of 381 and 353 g mol−1 were assumed according to MS analyses. The presence of ion fragments at m/z 366 (−16) and m/z 338 (−16) in the case of products I and II respectively indicated CH4 loss from these two compounds. A similar loss with equivalent ions was observed in negative APCI mode. N-oxide derivative structures similar to those previously reported (De Witte et al., 2009) could favour the loss of this fragment in the ionisation source. For these two compounds, the MS/MS spectrum fragmentation of ions at m/z 366 or 338 gave ions which could correspond to CO2 (−44), CO (−28) or H2O (−18) loss. The chemical structures presented in Table 1 were thus suggested on the basis of the well-known ozone reactivity with unsaturated and tertiary amine compounds (). These structures are in agreement with the observed UV spectrum. The reaction pathway presented in Fig. 4 was estimated from these transformation products. An initial ozone attack on N′4 atom of the piperazinyl moiety of LVF is proposed on the basis of previous findings relative to the reactivity of ozone (). This ozone attack could give either the N-oxide LVF derivative (intermediate A) or product III after formation of an amine radical cation (Muñoz and Von Sonntag, 2000). According to the known reactivity of ozone towards unsaturated compounds (), a cyclo-addition on the 2–3 double bond of the quinolonic moiety of LVF, intermediate A and product III could occur and give rise to intermediate C, product I and intermediate B via an unstable ozonide. These latter compounds would further decompose into products II and IV after a successive decarboxylation and oxidation reaction.
Formation of transformation products and toxicity study

Ozonation experiments were performed with an initial LVF concentration of 1 g L−1 in order to assess the toxicity pattern of ozonated LVF in aqueous solutions. Under these conditions, the ozone mass balance showed 46 mg of ozone consumption for 80% of LVF degraded after 15 min of ozonation. The LVF toxicity and transformation products patterns are presented in Fig. 5. The results showed a gradual increase in toxicity during LVF ozonation up to nearly 95% inhibition of bacteria luminescence for 90 min ozonation, while LVF was completely degraded after 40 min (Fig. 5a). Ozone could not account for the observed toxicity since no residual of ozone was measured before the toxicity tests. The LC analyses revealed that the transformation products identified in this study, progressively disappeared after complete removal of LVF (Fig. 5b). Therefore, these compounds could not account for the observed luminescence inhibition, and formation of one or several other toxic transformation products refractory to ozone and HO radicals could be formed. Otherwise, according to Shen et al. (1989), the ability of fluoroquinolones to inhibit bacterial activity is known to be linked to the quinolone moiety. As shown in Table 1, chemical structures of the products I, II and IV indicate that ozone attack occurred on the quinolone moiety of LVF. No antibacterial activity of the identified products I, II and IV could therefore be expected.
Conclusions

The kinetics of LVF oxidation by ozone and hydroxyl radicals in pure water were studied using ozonation and H2O2/UV systems. The rate constant values indicated that both systems were able to remove this pharmaceutical (i.e. kO3/LVF=6.0×104M-1s-1 and kHO /LVF=5.2×109M-1s-1 at pH 7.2; kHO /LVF=4.5×109M-1s-1 at pH 6.0). The behaviour of LVF in a real water treatment ozonation process was modelled on the basis of the Rct concept. Under these conditions, for a residual ozone concentration of 0.4 mg L−1, a 1.38 s half-life was expected during ozonation of water. Due to the high reactivity of LVF with ozone, LVF oxidation during ozonation of real waters occurs mostly via direct attack of molecular ozone. Moreover, despite the high kinetic rate constant kHO /LVF obtained, HO radicals did not participate in the oxidation reaction during LVF ozonation. Four transformation products were detected and identified during the ozonation experiments. Two products (I and II) might have been formed by successive direct attack of ozone on the double bond of the quinolonic moiety followed by decarboxylation, and on the tertiary amine of the piperazinyl moiety, leading to the formation of N-oxide derivatives. The other products (III and IV) could come from an initial attack of the tertiary amine of the piperazinyl group with loss of a methyl group, followed by an attack on the double bond of the quinolonic moiety and decarboxylation. Finally, the toxicity clearly increased according to the inhibition luminescence of V. fisheri bacteria, while all identified products were completely removed after 90 min of ozonation. LVF ozonation could thus lead to the formation of further transformation products that are more toxic to V. fisheri than pharmaceuticals and resistant to ozone.
